title: Jay Taylor (placekicker)
text:
James "Jay" Taylor (born October 23, 1976 in <a href="Hershey%2C%20Pennsylvania">Hershey</a>, <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>) is a former <a href="United%20States">American</a> professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> <a href="Placekicker">kicker</a>. He played <a href="College%20football">collegiately</a> for the <a href="West%20Virginia%20Mountaineers">West Virginia Mountaineers</a>.
High school years.
Taylor attended <a href="Hershey%20High%20School%20%28Pennsylvania%29">Hershey High School</a> in Hershey, Pennsylvania and starred in <a href="High%20school%20football">football</a>, <a href="soccer">soccer</a>, and <a href="tennis">tennis</a>. In football, he was an All-Conference selection.
College career.
Taylor attended <a href="West%20Virginia%20University">West Virginia University</a> and was a student and a four-year <a href="Letterman%20%28sports%29">letterman</a> in <a href="College%20football">football</a>. Taylor played both kicker and <a href="Punter%20%28American%20football%29">punter</a> in his four-year career from 1996 to 1999.
In his sophomore season in 1997, Taylor kicked a career-long 52-yard <a href="Field%20goal%20%28football%29">field goal</a> against <a href="University%20of%20Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a> in the <a href="Backyard%20Brawl">Backyard Brawl</a>.
Against <a href="Ohio%20State%20Buckeyes%20football">Ohio State</a>, as a junior in 1998, Taylor punted for a career-high 410 yards. Against <a href="Virginia%20Tech%20Hokies%20football">Virginia Tech</a> that same season, Taylor had a career-long 63-yard punt.
Professional career.
Miami Dolphins.
Jay Taylor was signed as an <a href="undrafted%20free%20agent">undrafted free agent</a> by the <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> in 2000. Taylor was cut shortly afterwards.
Orlando Rage.
He was selected by the <a href="Orlando%20Rage">Orlando Rage</a> of the <a href="XFL%20%282001%29">XFL</a> in the <a href="2001%20XFL%20Draft">2001 XFL Draft</a>, where he played both kicker and punter.
Buffalo Bills.
After the XFL season ended, the <a href="Buffalo%20Bills">Buffalo Bills</a> signed him to the preseason roster, primarily as a punter. He lost the competition to <a href="Brian%20Moorman">Brian Moorman</a> and was waived during the preseason.
Rhein Fire.
In 2003, he played for the <a href="Rhein%20Fire">Rhein Fire</a> of <a href="NFL%20Europe">NFL Europe</a>, allocated from the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>.
Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
He was a member of the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Buccaneers">Tampa Bay Buccaneers</a> <a href="practice%20squad">practice squad</a> in 2004 and was activated by the Bucs that year, playing in 5 games.
Orlando Predators.
After being cut by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in 2005, Taylor was signed by the <a href="Orlando%20Predators">Orlando Predators</a> of the <a href="Arena%20Football%20League%20%281987%E2%80%932008%29">Arena Football League</a> on June 30, 2006.
Taylor entered the 2008 season as the franchise leader in single-season field goal percentage, career field goal percentage, single-season extra point percentage, career extra point percentage, consecutive extra points made, and consecutive field goals made. He also won the 2004 Kicker of the Year award with the Predators.
